Water Conservation

What is Water Conservation?

Water conservation is the practice of efficiently using water to reduce unnecessary water usage.

Turn Off the Water

Turn off the faucet while brushing your teeth or shaving. Every bit of water conservation helps!

Water Plants Wisely

The best time to water your lawn or garden is first thing in the morning or late in the evening. At these times, water will not evaporate as quickly.

Check For and Repair Leaks

Every year, an average of 10,000 gallons of water is wasted due to household leaks. Make sure to repair leaky toilets and faucets.

Use a Dishwasher

Using a dishwasher is more water efficient than hand washing your dishes, especially if you run a full load.

Take Shorter Showers

Typically, a shower uses 5-10 gallons of water every minute. Limit your showers to 5 minutes or less.

Use a Broom

Do not use a hose to clean your driveways and sidewalks. Instead, use a broom.

Avoid Flushing Tissues

Rather than flushing tissues down the toilet, drop them in the trash instead. This saves water every time.

Share Your Knowledge!

Perhaps one of the most important things you can do to conserve water is share your knowledge about saving water with your neighbors, friends, and family.

So What?

Fresh, clean water is one of our most precious resources on Earth that is becoming more limited every day. Approximately 70% of the Earth is made up of water, and many parts of the world suffer from clean water shortage. It is vitally important to conserve water because it keeps water clean and pure while protecting the environment.
